title: Epic 6: Web Interface & Documentation
tagline: The user-facing experience: professional presentation and comprehensive documentation

productManager.narrative: I spawned the sixth and final team-lead with anticipation—this would transform raw functionality into polished educational product. The logs showed the team-lead verifying all five previous completion files existed. This was critical: Epic 6 was responsible for ALL documentation (Epics 1-5 created none). I watched as three specialists were spawned: Web Interface Specialist, Documentation Writer, and Integration Tester. This epic would take longer—creating index.html and learn.html, writing six documentation files (INSTALL.md, CONFIGURATION.md, TROUBLESHOOTING.md, TECHNICAL_SPECS.md, EDUCATOR_GUIDE.md, README.md), testing end-to-end. Hours passed. I saw HTML files appear with dark theme (#1a1a1a background, #ff6b35 orange accents, #ffffff white text). Documentation files materialized one by one, each comprehensive and professional. The integration tester ran through setup flows, notebook execution, evaluation system. When .epic6_complete.json appeared, I reviewed everything: professional web interface, complete documentation suite, successful end-to-end tests. The project was ready for students. Felix's automated development challenge was nearly complete.

teamLead.narrative: I was the final team-lead, tasked with creating the user-facing experience. My first critical action: verify ALL previous completion files existed. I checked .epic1_complete.json through .epic5_complete.json—all present, all showing 'completed: true'. The infrastructure was solid. My mission was dual: create professional web interface and write comprehensive documentation. This was the largest scope yet: 2 HTML files, 6 documentation files, complete testing. I consulted the meta-agent, spawning three specialists. To the Web Interface Specialist: 'Create index.html as navigation hub with welcome, documentation links, lesson launch, setup validation. Create learn.html for lesson preparation with attention theory, mathematics, visual explanations. Use dark theme: #1a1a1a background, #ff6b35 orange accents, #ffffff white text. Professional, minimalist, accessible (WCAG 2.1 AA).' To the Documentation Writer: 'Write INSTALL.md (installation), CONFIGURATION.md (LLM setup), TROUBLESHOOTING.md (common issues), TECHNICAL_SPECS.md (system requirements), EDUCATOR_GUIDE.md (instructor guide), update README.md (project overview). Make comprehensive and professional.' To the Integration Tester: 'Validate complete system: setup flow, notebook execution, evaluation, documentation accuracy, web links.' I coordinated their work, ensuring consistency. When all reported completion, I compiled .epic6_complete.json—the final epic completion file.

specialists.narrative: I was tasked with creating the professional entry point. File 1: index.html. I designed a navigation hub with sections: Welcome (project overview, learning objectives), Documentation (links to all 6 .md files), Getting Started (link to learn.html, environment setup instructions), Launch Lesson (button to start Jupyter), Setup Validation (checks for Python, dependencies, notebooks). The design followed specifications exactly: background #1a1a1a (dark charcoal), headings and accents #ff6b35 (vibrant orange), body text #ffffff (white), secondary text #cccccc (light gray). I used system fonts for fast loading, flexbox for responsive layout, CSS grid for documentation links. Accessibility: semantic HTML5, ARIA labels, keyboard navigation, sufficient color contrast (4.5:1). File 2: learn.html. This was pure education: Section 1: What is Attention? (intuitive explanation), Section 2: The Mathematics (Q, K, V projections, scaled dot-product, softmax), Section 3: Visual Intuition (attention as weighted lookup), Section 4: What You'll Implement (preview of 4 sections), Section 5: Prerequisites (Python, PyTorch basics). I included SVG diagrams showing attention architecture. Same dark theme, same accessibility standards. Navigation: header with link back to index.html. The interface was professional, clean, and ready for educational institutions.
challenges: Creating professional design with specific color requirements
Balancing educational content with clean interface
Making interface work offline after setup
solutions: Strictly followed color scheme, tested contrast ratios
Implemented semantic HTML, ARIA labels, keyboard navigation
Used only local resources—no CDN dependencies

specialists.narrative: I was responsible for ALL documentation—previous epics created none. Six files to write. INSTALL.md: Step-by-step installation (Python setup, running setup_venv.sh, dependency installation, verification). Platform-specific instructions for Windows/Mac/Linux. CONFIGURATION.md: LLM configuration for evaluation system. Ollama setup (installation, model download, configuration), OpenAI setup (API key, configuration), editing .llm_config.json. TROUBLESHOOTING.md: Common issues with solutions (Python not found, dependency errors, Jupyter issues, LLM connection failures, evaluation errors). Debug steps for each. TECHNICAL_SPECS.md: System requirements (Python 3.8+, 8GB RAM, 2GB disk), dependency list with versions, architecture overview, tensor shapes, cell structure. EDUCATOR_GUIDE.md: For instructors (learning objectives, prerequisite knowledge, estimated time, facilitation tips, evaluation system explanation, customization options). README.md update: Complete project overview, quick start, features, project structure, credits. Each file was comprehensive, professionally written, technically accurate. I referenced all five previous epics' outputs, ensuring documentation matched implementation exactly.
challenges: Writing comprehensive documentation for complex system
Ensuring accuracy across all five epics' implementations
solutions: Structured each file with clear sections and examples
Used progressive disclosure: simple quick-start, then detailed explanations
Read all completion files to verify technical accuracy

specialists.narrative: I validated the complete system end-to-end. Test 1: Setup Flow. Followed INSTALL.md instructions: ran setup_venv.sh, verified virtual environment created, checked all dependencies installed, confirmed Python version. Success. Test 2: Notebook Execution. Opened complete_lesson.ipynb, ran all cells sequentially. Section 1 (Linear Projections): Q, K, V computed correctly, visualization displayed. Section 2 (Attention Scores): scores computed, heatmap displayed. Section 3 (Softmax): weights sum to 1.0, visualization clear. Section 4 (Value Aggregation): attended_values correct shape. Demonstration section: model loaded from cache, comparison displayed. Success. Test 3: Evaluation System. Ran grade_notebook('lesson.ipynb'). LLM connected (Ollama), evaluated empty TODOs, scored 0 with feedback 'Implementation missing.' Ran on complete_lesson.ipynb, scored 95-100 with positive feedback. Success. Test 4: Documentation Accuracy. Verified all file paths, commands, and technical details in documentation matched actual implementation. Test 5: Web Interface. Opened index.html, clicked all links, verified all documentation accessible, tested learn.html. Success. All tests passed. System ready for students.
